attachments.text: :white_check_mark: All checks have passed

This ports over the API documentation from KERIpy to KERIA with one notable difference being the use of the newest version of the OpenAPI spec version 3.1.0. This is much newer than the 3.0.2 version used in KERIpy.

See <https://lornajane.net/posts/2020/whats-new-in-openapi-3-1|this article> for what else is new in 3.1.0 vs 3.0.x and <https://www.openapis.org/blog/2021/02/16/migrating-from-openapi-3-0-to-3-1-0|this migration guide> for guidance on migration. We didn't have to do any migration work since we weren't doing anything fancy.

The short version of the upgrade is that it uses pure JSON Schema and has support for defining webhooks in an API specification, a much-awaited feature. A number of quality of life improvements have come out since 2018 when the <https://github.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/blob/main/versions/3.0.2.md|3.0.2 spec> came out. The <https://github.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/blob/main/versions/3.1.0.md|newest spec> came out in 2021 though the tooling supporting it, including Swagger UI, has taken some time to catch up.

This PR uses the latest release of Swagger UI at <https://github.com/swagger-api/swagger-ui/releases/tag/v5.0.0-alpha.9|5.0.0-alpha.9>. The first release to support partial rendering of JSON Schema in Swagger UI is <https://github.com/swagger-api/swagger-ui/releases/tag/v5.0.0-alpha.7|5.0.0-alpha.7>

Here's a teaser of this in action:  
<https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/65027257/236344733-f7169322-19d1-47c3-a0aa-e410b56be51a.png|KERI Swagger UI with OpenAPI 3.1.0>
attachments.title: <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/keria/pull/31|#31 API Docs with OpenAPI 3.1.0>

attachments.text:
*About Keria API and HTTP Message Signatures*

I'd like to create a "generic" API client for Keria. With dependencies to 3rd party libraries supporting crypto and http message signatures only. I don't know if this is feasible or not but I'm giving it a try.

While reviewing the HTTP Message Signature implementation of keria/signifypy I have found a couple of potential interop issues.

These are the Signature and Signature-Input headers from keria <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/keria/blob/906b1029e45757200a4c7fa4d5a0eaf0c40be1df/tests/core/test_authing.py#L54|test_authing.py>:

```
Signature: indexed="?0";signify="0BA9SX7Jyn66ZdCPOb0WqDEn1UC49GeSPypjVgeMrt6VLWKjEw9ij7Ndur7Wcrru_5eQNbSiNaiP4NQYWht5srEL"
Signature-Input: signify=("signify-resource" "@method" "@path" "signify-timestamp");created=1609459200;keyid="EJPEPKslRHD_fkug3zmoyjQ90DazQAYWI8JIrV2QXyhg";alg="ed25519"
```

From HTTP Message Signatures about the <https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-httpbis-message-signatures-17.html#name-the-signature-http-field|Signature> header:

> The member's key is the label that uniquely identifies the message signature within the HTTP message. The member's value is a Byte Sequence containing the signature value for the message signature identified by the label.

For better interop the key ("signify") should uniquely identify this message. The Signature header then looks like this:

```
Signature: signify="0BA9SX7Jyn66ZdCPOb0WqDEn1UC49GeSPypjVgeMrt6VLWKjEw9ij7Ndur7Wcrru_5eQNbSiNaiP4NQYWht5srEL";indexed="?0"
```

For the CESR encoded signature value I think there are two options:

1. Remove the CESR code prefix "0B", then encode the payload as base64 (with padding, not url safe)
2. Transform the CESR signature value into B-domain, then encode as base64 (not url safe). Introduce KERI CESR specific signature alg name for example "keri-ed25519" (or simply "keri-signature" as the CESR signature value already identifies the algorithm)

With option 1) and correct datatypes of <https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8941#name-byte-sequences|Byte Sequence> and <https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8941#name-booleans|Boolean> the value looks like this:

```
Signature: signify=:hPSaI922OvLC0M8WMQoEDgt7xFoby6KX0JNW/8KMeaqpMoTu/0lrhKiZNbHwC0IdXk9ur3Ud2k6i/v5VOFIbBg==:;indexed=?0
```

I don't know if HTTP Message Signatures allows extending the Signature value with parameters. To avoid interop issues I'd suggest moving the "indexed" parameter to the Signature-Input header. This way the parameter is also included in the signed payload.

The Signature and Signature-Input headers then look like this:

```
Signature: signify=:hPSaI922OvLC0M8WMQoEDgt7xFoby6KX0JNW/8KMeaqpMoTu/0lrhKiZNbHwC0IdXk9ur3Ud2k6i/v5VOFIbBg==:
Signature-Input: signify=("@method" "@path" "content-length" "signify-resource" "signify-timestamp");created=1609459200;keyid="EICwDc-jYoUgNyMlAdg2iOFyeu56-RXvPRdFCG2luers";alg="ed25519";indexed=?0
```

The second option uses alg="keri-ed25519" and looks like this:

```
Signature: signify=:0BCE9Joj3bY68sLQzxYxCgQOC3vEWhvLopfQk1b/wox5qqkyhO7/SWuEqJk1sfALQh1eT26vdR3aTqL+/lU4UhsG:
Signature-Input: signify=("@method" "@path" "content-length" "signify-resource" "signify-timestamp");created=1609459200;keyid="EICwDc-jYoUgNyMlAdg2iOFyeu56-RXvPRdFCG2luers";alg="keri-ed25519";indexed=?0
```

*References*

• <https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-httpbis-message-signatures-17.html|https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-httpbis-message-signatures-17.html>
• <https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8941|https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8941>

attachments.text:
In the current implementation of delegated inception and rotation (including in multisig delegation), the delegate controller waits for delegation approval before publishing the event to the witnesses. Since the witnesses are under the control of the controller, this order should be inverted.

To accomplish this, witnesses should accept delegated AID events without requiring a delegator approval anchor but not publish the events externally until the delegator's approval anchor is received. Once watchers are in place the witnesses can publish the event externally without the approval because the watcher's won't accept the event until the approval shows up.
attachments.title: <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/keria/issues/36|#36 Fix order of witness receipts relative to delegation approval.>

attachments.text: The idea is to have a way for a Signify client to backup all its information held by KERIA and be able to restore it into another instance of KERIA. It can be seen as a backup of KERIA, but also as a portability feature so a client can move away from a KERIA agent to another.
attachments.title: <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/keria/issues/37|#37 Implement backup and restore>

text: Shifting focus to automating the delegation integration test stuff now, so it’s easier for others

elements.text: Shifting focus to automating the delegation integration test stuff now, so it’s easier for others

attachments.text:
The delegation integration test requires:

1. Clean KERIPY witness network
2. Clean Running KERIA
3. KERIPY delegator (init, incept, delegation confirmation)
4. Signify delegate (init, boot agent, delegator oobi resolve, incept w/ delpre)

Create a script that combines these for ease of use.

`keyid`="Key identifier for the signing and verification keys used to create this signature"

To follow the spec, I'm changing the `keyid` from the `agent.pre` to the `controller.pre`

attachments.title: <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/signify-ts/issues/29|#29 Add save and delete SALTs on SignifyClient>

attachments.text:
*Inception*

A Signify client will initialize itself by asking for the passcode and using it to create (passcode is bran that is stretched to become a ed25519 seed) the AEID (non-transferable identifier) for both keystore encryption (ed25519 key -> x25519 key) and request signing. Alongside that AEID key, the signify client has the option to create one of two things:

1. A second pre-rotated key AEID' and returning the passcode for that key to the controller to save as a "recovery key", sending a Blake3 hash of the AEID' to the Agent as the prior next digest.
2. A random salt for a hierarchically deterministic key chain from which is will generate AEID'(0) returning the salt to the controller to save as the "recovery key" (how to handle index?) sending a Blake3 hash of the AEID'(0) to the Agent as the prior next digest.

The choice between a random AEID' and one based on an HD key chain is a tradeoff between usability and security. Using the random AEID' requires the Signify client to generate a new AEID returning a new passcode to the controller as the new "recovery key" for each rotation. An HD keychain would allow the controller the opportunity to keep the same "recovery key" between rotations at the expense of some predictability of the next keys.

A Signify client will send the AEID and a Black3 hash of AEID' to the Agent to create a key store, for example in a POST to `/keystore/signify-0`

```
{
    "aeid": "BPreeb3HxvtWDv4M81sqG7oJcH3FRp5InzvZdHV-vu-3",
    "ndig": "EBhBRqVbqhhP7Ciah5pMIOdsY5Mm1ITm2Fjqb028tylu"
}
```

In this example, the Agent will create a keystore using `signify-0` as the name, AEID is the current encryption public key for the key store and the current signing public key for requests to the agent for key store `signify-0`. All other API requests to the agent for keystore `signify-0` will need to be signed with the private key for the AEID of this keystore.

*Rotation*

To perform a rotation of the AEID, the Signify client would perform a PUT to the `/keystore/signify-0` endpoint with AEID' now in the`aeid` field and signed by the private key of AEID'. The Agent will verify that the prior next digest is a Blake3 hash of AEID' and that the current request is signed by the private key of AEID' and replace the current AEID with AEID'. In addition, the Signify client will return a Blake3 hash of a new prior next key as determine by the choice between random and HD key chains. With a random key generation strategy, a new "recovery key" must be returned to the controller to save in a safe place for the next rotation. With HD key chain, no new "recovery key" is needed.

```
{
    "aeid": "BDZbG0DmL0Q4eaRSzWNNjhaEZUvZRYPZ3z7Q90zTmOA6",
    "ndig": "EA_F5PWSZCN1Bns19Ns_DIsMGTuIKR-QPorkBfUM1_fU"
}
```

*Outstanding Issues*

☐ For HD key chain, is it safe to start with the salt and generate keys until we find the current AEID when performing a rotation or will the user need to save a "current index"?
☐ When performing a rotation, when and how are the keys re-encrypted? It seems that they must be included in the PUT call to `/keystore/{name}` so the newly encrypted keys are saved in one "transaction" with the new AEID. Is that the correct assumption?

The delegation integration test requires:

1. Clean KERIPY witness network
2. Clean Running KERIA
3. KERIPY delegator (init, incept, delegation confirmation)
4. Signify delegate (init, boot agent, delegator oobi resolve, incept w/ delpre)

Create a script that combines these for ease of use.

attachments.text: :white_check_mark: No checks have passed

Adds support using a long running operation for monitoring and waiting on the creation of a credential registry.

This also finishes the `Registries.registryIncept` function which previously did not contain the creation of an anchor Seal for the registry nor the interaction event to add the registry anchor Seal to the KERIA controller's KEL.

attachments.text:
I wanted to create a new class that allows to push events that are happening inside the cloud agent to other backend processes.  
It is similar to the notifier class but it is used to "notify" other web services.  
I would like to notify the web services of the following event:  
simple aid inception  
simple aid rotation  
simple aid delegation  
multisig aid inception  
multisig aid rotation  
multisig aid delegation  
multisig request  
multisig signatures  
acdc issuance  
acdc revocation  
acdc presentation

attachments.text: :white_check_mark: All checks have passed

This PR includes a new API for searching for credentials held or issued by AIDs in an Agent. It uses the SAD path language for referencing fields in a credential and allows for specification of multiple criteria in a dictionary structure keyed by the SAD path reference. Currently only the $eq and $begins operators are support. Ascending sort order for all fields is also supported.

This will be helpful for holders of credentials for sure but the main use case we are trying to address is for credential issuers that need more advance credential management than holders. So a query to answer the quesiton:

> “Show me all the ECR credentials I issued with LEI ‘xyz’, sorted by date, page size 20 at a time.”

Could be expressed with this API as:

```
seeker.find(
      {
         '-i': {'$eq': issuerHab.pre},
         '-a-LEI': {'$eq': 'xyz'},
         '-s': {'$eq': 'ECR_SCHEMA_SAID'}
      })
        .sort(['-a-dt']).limit(20)
```

The Seeker object creates indexes in LMDB for all base fields in an ACDC credential and all top level fields with scalar values in the payload of any loaded credential. In addition, multiple column indexes are created for the following combinations:

• Issuer/Schema
• Issuee/Schema
• Issuer/
• Issuee/
• Issuer/Schema/
• Issuee/Schema/

All other criteria combinations will use the indexes they can and perform a full table scan as a last resort. One key limitation is that criteria must be specified in the correct order listed above to make use of the multi-column index. This should be improved later..

Skip and Limit parameters are provided to enable pagination. Sort order will determine page order or the lexicographic order or the SAIDs of the credentials.

This API will be exposed through the REST API that is _currently_ limited to only listing "my issued" or "my received" credentials.

All other criteria combinations will use the indexes they can and perform a full table scan as a last resort. One key limitation is that criteria must be specified in the correct order listed above to make use of the multi-column index. This should be improved later..

Skip and Limit parameters are provided to enable pagination. Sort order will determine page order or the lexicographic order or the SAIDs of the credentials.

This API will be exposed through the REST API that is _currently_ limited to only listing "my issued" or "my received" credentials.

attachments.text: `<https://github.com/WebOfTrust/keria/commit/428ccbc7d1dc23c4fe3d8a6621bababb7ea19a27|428ccbc7>` - Advanced credential searching and sorting API (#68)

This PR includes a new API for searching for credentials held or issued by AIDs in an Agent. It uses the SAD path language for referencing fields in a credential and allows for specification of multiple criteria in a dictionary structure keyed by the SAD path reference. Currently only the $eq and $begins operators are support. Ascending sort order for all fields is also supported.

This will be helpful for holders of credentials for sure but the main use case we are trying to address is for credential issuers that need more advance credential management than holders. So a query to answer the quesiton:

> “Show me all the ECR credentials I issued with LEI ‘xyz’, sorted by date, page size 20 at a time.”

Could be expressed with this API as:

```
seeker.find(
      {
         '-i': {'$eq': issuerHab.pre},
         '-a-LEI': {'$eq': 'xyz'},
         '-s': {'$eq': 'ECR_SCHEMA_SAID'}
      })
        .sort(['-a-dt']).limit(20)
```

The Seeker object creates indexes in LMDB for all base fields in an ACDC credential and all top level fields with scalar values in the payload of any loaded credential. In addition, multiple column indexes are created for the following combinations:

• Issuer/Schema
• Issuee/Schema
• Issuer/
• Issuee/
• Issuer/Schema/
• Issuee/Schema/

All other criteria combinations will use the indexes they can and perform a full table scan as a last resort. One key limitation is that criteria must be specified in the correct order listed above to make use of the multi-column index. This should be improved later..

Skip and Limit parameters are provided to enable pagination. Sort order will determine page order or the lexicographic order or the SAIDs of the credentials.

This API will be exposed through the REST API that is _currently_ limited to only listing "my issued" or "my received" credentials.

The goal is to improve the `SignifyClient` interface following TS conventions:

• improve TS typing; avoid the use of `any` types
• use of object parameter instead on having too many optional parameters (reducing the number of `undefined` passed to the function)
• use of lowerCamelCase in function and parameter names

attachments.text:
Adds support using a long running operation for monitoring and waiting on the creation of a credential registry.

This also finishes the `Registries.registryIncept` function which previously did not contain the creation of an anchor Seal for the registry nor the interaction event to add the registry anchor Seal to the KERIA controller's KEL.

attachments.text: :white_check_mark: All checks have passed

Liveness checks and readiness checks facilitate stability and functionality for container deployment technology like Kubernetes for the following purposes:

1. Permitting routing of requests to a Kubernetes Pod only when it is ready to receive requests. This avoids unnecessarily causing client side errors or potential server side crashes.
2. Continuous health monitoring of pods. When a pod crashes or becomes unstable then Kubernetes will detect the poor health and automatically restart it. This may or may not make problems worse, though it usually makes them better.

Doing health checks in KERIA is challenging because of the following concerns:

1. A health check of the overall Agency is different than a health check on a particular agent.
2. A KERIA Agency may have hundreds of Agents. Should a global health check include an agent-specific check for every agent?
3. Which endpoint should the healthcheck be available on?
    • 3901 (admin)
    • 3902 (http)
    • 3903 (boot)
attachments.title: <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/keria/issues/99|#99 Liveness and readiness health check endpoints>

attachments.text:
In order to support TLS termination at the witness we need to expose the following options on the `keria start` command:

• `--keypath`
• `--certpath`
• `--cafilepath`

As these options are already exposed on the KERIpy `kli agent start` command it is hopefully straightforward to expose these options for `kli witness start` since both use the HIO library underneath.

Example code for CLI command:

• <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/keripy/blob/development/src/keri/app/cli/commands/agent/start.py#L57|kli agent start> code
• <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/keripy/blob/405b26b73d21d0ce155f48dd1f2afdb9ef0cf48b/src/keri/app/booting.py#L85|keri.app.booting.py> example of using an `hio.core.tcp.ServerTls` instance.
    
    ```
    servant = hio.core.tcp.ServerTls(certify=False,
                                                      keypath=self.keypath,
                                                      certpath=self.certpath,
                                                      cafilepath=self.cafilepath,
                                                      port=self.port)
    ```
attachments.title: <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/keria/issues/100|#100 Add TLS options for Agent, can pull from KERIpy Agent>

I think there's an anti-pattern in the integration tests in singify-ts/examples

All of the .ts files start with this declaration  
`let signify: any;`

This effectively disables any type checking by the typescript compiler, VS Code and other tools

This pull request is a suggestion how to fix this. If this pattern is acceptable then the other scripts should be fixed as well.
attachments.title: <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/signify-ts/pull/104|#104 Fix integration scripts type checking>

attachments.text:
I wanted to create a new class that allows to push events that are happening inside the cloud agent to other backend processes.  
It is similar to the notifier class but it is used to "notify" other web services.  
I would like to notify the web services of the following event:  
simple aid inception  
simple aid rotation  
simple aid delegation  
multisig aid inception  
multisig aid rotation  
multisig aid delegation  
multisig request  
multisig signatures  
acdc issuance  
acdc revocation  
acdc presentation
